position.marginalia_text: Pla[e]rique Omnes excellentissimi, plus pra[e] se, quàm in se, ferunt / Scientia[e], et Virtutis.

marginalia.translation: Many of the most excellent men boast of knowledge and virtue rather than having it.

position.marginalia_text: Quorsum ha[e]c? ( Prima semper qua[e]stio. ( Quis valor istorum pra[e]ceptoru[m]? Quid magni potest hoc studiu[m]?

marginalia.translation: To what end is this thing? Always the first question. What is the value of those precepts? What is the greatness of this study?

position.marginalia_text: ) Plus valet Hoc vnum ad unguem, quàm ) Illa Centum ad Manum.

marginalia.translation: This one thing learned by heart is worth more than one hundred of that other thing at hand.

position.marginalia_text: A great treasure in a little casket. A chymique dramme, more then a grose pound. The long Earth in a short Mapp.
Mentis magnitudo, pro Artium, virtutumq[ue] quantitate.

marginalia.translation: Greatness of mind, for a multitude of skills and virtues.

position.marginalia_text: Epictetus, et Vrso: Hermes, et Diocles: Dion, et Mithridates in Suo Epicyclo.

marginalia.translation: Epictetus and Urso: Hermes and Diocles: Dion and Mithridates in his epicycle.

position.marginalia_text: Ciuilis Confidentia, hodiè multò valentior, quàm Modestia.

marginalia.translation: Daily civic trust is much more valuable than modesty.

position.marginalia_text: Stulti est, non scire: ignaui, non probare: miseri, non posse.

marginalia.translation: Foolish is he who does not know. Lazy is he who does not try. Wretched is he who is incapable.
